Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: You see a coworker about to walk under a suspended load, and you must shout to warn them instantly.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow, the clang of metal and the hum of machinery filling the air. As a construction laborer, I knew safety was everything. My supervisor always said, “Keep your eyes open, keep your crew safe.” Just as I was about to leave for my volunteer shift at the community kitchen, I spotted Joe, headphones in, about to walk under a massive load dangling from the crane. My heart pounded. I had to shout, to warn him—no question. But my phone buzzed in my pocket: a reminder that my volunteer shift started in ten minutes across town. They counted on me to be on time, to set an example. Still, I knew the kitchen would be fine for a while without me; there were plenty of hands today. But here, on this site, one careless moment could mean disaster. I stood frozen, torn between the urgent need to keep my coworker safe and the commitment I’d made to the people waiting for me at the kitchen.
